DIV1.P: THE GAMESTER: A Comedy. As it is Acted at the New-Theatre IN LINCOLNS-INN-FIELDS, BY Her Majesty's SERVANTS.
LONDON: Printed for William Turner, at the Angel at Lincolns-Inn Back-Gate, and William Davis at the Black-Bull in Cornhill. 1705.

Lately Published Aristotle's Art of Poetry. Translated from the Original Greek, according to Mr. Theodore Goulston's Edition, together with Mr. D' Acier's Notes Translated from the French. By William Maundij, M. D. Sold by William Turner. Price 6 s.

DIV1.HEAD: TO THE Right Honourable GEORGE EARL OF Huntingdon.
DIV1.P: THE Kind Reception this Play has met with from the Town, gives me some Hopes of Your Lord∣ship's Acceptance, since amongst our English Noblemen none is more conspicuously grac'd with those Qualifications that render a Soul truly Generous, than Your Lordhip's; You have given the World sufficient Proof that You prefer the Service of Your Country to any Plea∣sure whatsoever; in You, the Peer is shown without the Vanity, and the Inherent Virtue without the common Vice; the Actions of Your Life File the Teeth of Satyr, as much as others give 'em an Edge; Strangers Admire, while Friends Adore Your Conduct.

The Design of this Piece were to divert, without that Vicious Strain which usually attends the Comick Muse, and according to the first intent of Plays, recommend Mora∣lity,
and I hope I have in some measure, perform'd it; I dare affirm there is nothing Immodest, nor immoral in it; part of it I own my self oblig'd to the French for particular∣ly the Character of the Gamester; but he is intirely ru∣in'd in the French: whereas I, in Complaisance to the many fine Gentlemen that Play in England, have reclaim'd him, after I have discover'd the ill Consequence of Gaming, that very often happen to those who are too passi∣onately fond of it; I shall not inlarge upon the Altera∣tions, but refer Your Lordship to the Original, who are a perfect Master in that Tongue.

I heartily wish all Men of Rank and Quality as indif∣ferent to this bewitching Diversion of Gameing as Your Lordship; then wou'd the Distress'd be reliev'd, the Poor supported, and the Virtuous encourag'd, which would di∣stinguish our Nobility as much above our Neighbours, as their Heroick Deeds have done.

But You, My Lord, pursue a Nobler End, and have chose rather to stain the Field with the Blood of Your Nation's Enemies, than encrease Your Fortune by ano∣ther's Ruin; or expose Your Own to the Hazardous Die, a Resolution worthy of Your Birth and Fortune: And that You may live to be a Terrour to our Foes, and a Succour to Your Country, in perfect Health and Happiness, till Your Dearest Friends consent to part with You, are the Humble Wishes of

SIGNED.HI: Your Lordship's Most Obedient, and Most Devoted Servant

DIV2.HEAD: ACT I. The Curtain draws up, and discovers Hector in an Arm'd-Chair just waking, yawning.
DIV2.P: BLESS me! 'tis broad Day-light! Who the Devil wou'd serve a Gamester? 'Tis a cursed Life, this that I lead. Oh, my dear Bed, how seldom do I visit thee! When shall I be lapt in the Fold of thy Embra∣ces, and snore forth my Thanks? I, that cou'd enjoy the Four and twenty Hours together, am grown a perfect Stran∣ger to thy Charms. Oh! my precious Master! Now, Ten to One, will he come home with an empty Pocket; and then will he be confoundedly out of Humour: Then sant I dare to ask him for any Dinner. Thus am I robb'd of the two chiefest Pleasures of my Life, Eating and Seeping.

SP.P: Good morrow, Monsieur Hector: Where is your sweet Master?
Asleep.
I must see him.
My Master sees no Body when he's asleep.
I must speak with him.
Indeed, sweet Mrs. Favourite, but you cannot.
P'shaw, I tell you I must, and will speak with him.
With who, Child?
With who? why, with Valere.
Heark'e, wou'd you speak with my Master in pro∣pria Persona, or with his Picture?
Leave Fooling, for I come not upon so merry a Message as you imagine.
Why then, to be serious, my Master is not come in: He's a Man of Business, Child, and neglects his Ease to follow that.

Yes, yes, I guess the Business; he is at shaking his Elbows over a Table; saying his Prayers backwards; courting the Dice like a Mistress, and cursing them when he is disappointed. Between you and I, Angelica knows his Extravagance; and finding he breaks all the Oaths he made against Play, resolves to see him no more.
If he has lost his Money, this News will break his Heart.
Tell him, that I say he has deceiv'd more Women than he has plaid Games at Hazard; and—
You say— Aye, I find Dorante, my Masters Uncl, has given you a retaining Fee: What shou'd she do wit that old Fellow?
Oh! he's a Lover ripe with Discretion.
Aye, but Women generally love green Fruit best; besides, my Master's handsome.

He handsome! Behold his Picture just as he'll ap∣pear this Morning, with Arms a-cross, down-cast Eyes, no Powder in his Perriwig; a Steenkirk tuck'd in to hide the Dirt, Sword-knot unty'd; no Gloves, and Hands and Face as dirty as a Tinker. This is the very Figure of your beautiful Master.
The Jade has hit it.
And Pocket as empty as a Capuchine.
Hold, hold, this is Spight, meer Spight and burn∣ing Envy.

Aye, 'tis no matter for that; I'll take care he shan't deceive my Mistress: For she that marries a Gamester that plays upon the Square, as the Fool your Master do's, can expect nothing but an Alms-House for a Jointure. Once more I tell you, that Dorante has both Reason and Favourite of his side.
And we have Love on our side; and Love never fails to conquer Reason: For your part you are like the Swiss, take any side for pay.
Is not Valere asham'd, the only Son of such a Fa∣mily, to leave his Father's House, and sneak up and down in Lodgings?
You're mistaken, Mrs. Favourite; he did not leave his Father's House: But his Father, who is as obstinate as the Devil, and as ill-natur'd as a Dutch-Man, turn'd him out.
He was a Dutiful Child in the mean time. Well, you may take my Word, he will have small Welcome at our House: I shall let my Lady know he is a Gaming; so, sweet Mr. Hector, adieu.
Farewel, Mrs. Fripry; I am glad I know my Ma∣ster's Enemy however. Ho! here he comes.
Sirrah, what's a Clock?
It is—in Troth, Sir, I have been up so long I have forgot.
Away, I am weary of your Fooleries. My Night-Gown, quick, quick, the Devil, the Devil.
Ah! I find where about he is, he swears between his Teeth.
So hey! What, must I wait all Day? my Gown here.Valere still walks about, and Hector still follow∣ing him with the Gown.
'Tis ready, Sir.

What a Dog am I? I know I have no luck, yet can't forbear playing. Oh, Fortune, Fortune! But why do I ex∣claim against her? I'll be even with her I warrant her; she has made me loose, but I defie her to make me pay, for the Devil a Sowse have I.
Sir, Sir, please to put on your Gown, Sir.
Get you to Bed, you Dog, and don't trouble me.
With all my Heart, Sir.Exit.

DIV2.STAGE: Valere sits down in the Arm'd-Chair.

SP.P: I think I am sleepy. Death! 'tis impossible to sleep: rises. For I can no sooner shut my Eyes, but methinks my Evil Genius flings Amm's Ace before me. Why, Hector, Sirrah; that Rogue sleeps happy: Why, Hector.
Sir—From the bottom of the Stage, unbutton'd.
Sir—You Sot, are you never tir'd with sleeping?
Tir'd—Why, Sir, I han't had time to unbutton my Coat yet.
Was any body here to ask for me?
Yes, Sir, Here was your Musick-Master and your Dancing-Master.
Ay, they want their Quarteridge, I suppose.
They'll call again▪ Sir.
Then Im not at home, Sir.
Oh! I know that, Sir. But, Sir, here was a kind of a — kind of a shabby-look'd Fellow—He said his Name was Cogdie: He'll call again too.
I know him not. None else?
Yes, Sir, a Back-Friend of yours. Sir, may I be so bold, as to ask you one Question? Do you love the charming Angelica?
Love her! I adore her!
Ah! that's an ill sign. Now do I know he has not a Penny in his Pocket. Ah, Sir, your Fob, like a Baromi∣ter, shews the Temper of your Heart, as that does the Weather.
Don't you imagine, whatever Passion I have for Play, that I have power to forget that Amiable Crea∣ture?
Ah, Sir, but if that Amiable Creature shou'd have banish'd you—
Impossible!

Talk not of Impossibilities, good Sir, for pert Mrs. Favourite is just gone; who, I find, hates you, and swears her Lady has declar'd for your Uncle. Ah, Sir— what she says is not altogether false; shaking his Head for notwithstanding you have sworn heartily to Angelica ne∣ver to play again, you do throw away a merry Main; or see, Sir—
Cease your Impertinence; I give you leave to jest upon my Losses; but my Mistress touches my Heart, Sir∣rah

Aside.Ah! Love's evour is always highest when the Cash is at an Ebb. But, Sir, be not cast down, I have heard 'em say, a new Passion is the only thing to cure an old one. There's the charming Widow of my
Lord Wealthy, her Sister richer than Angelica— Ah, Sir! had you but made your Addresses there.

There! she's the only Woman I wou'd avoid. She's a Coquet of the first rate; addresses all, and cares for none. How did she Tyrannize over my Friend Lovel before she married my Lord, though he is a Gentleman without Ex∣ception? And now she's playing the same Game over again; for the good-natur'd Fellow is in Love still.
Truly, Sir, I believe the French Marquiss will carry it.
No, he is too much of her Temper. Heark! who's there?
A Dun, I warrant.
I am not within, Sirrah.
Oh, Sir! your Father.
Ah! that's worse; now will he rail as heartily against Gaming, as the Whigs against Plays.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: What, are you up? this is not a Gamester's Hour, or have you not been in Bed all Night? that's most likely.
Aside.He's the Devil of a Guesser. Indeed my Master keeps as early Hours as any Man, I'll say that for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: Hold your Tongue, Sirrah, or I shall break your Head, your Freedom will not pass on me.
Your most humble Servant, Sir; I've done, Sir, I've done.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P:
I am come to make the last Tryal of you, Sir. Your Course of Life is so very scandalous, that unless I see a speedy and sincere Reformation, I have resolv'd to Dis-inherit you; then try if what has ruin'd you, will maintain you: But, do you hear, quit the Name of your An∣cestors,
who never yet produc'd such a Profligate. The Estate has not been reserv'd so long in the Family to be thrown away at Hazard.
Short and Pithy: We are in a hopeful way.
Sir, I have been revolving in my Mind all my Acts of Folly, and am asham'd that I harbour'd them so long, and now am arm'd with Manly Resolution; forgive my past Faults, and try my future Conduct.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: If I could believe thee real, my Joys would be compleat.
Ah! I smoak the design; a little Money is want∣ing.Aside.
My cruel Uncle, who never was a Friend to you, now endeavours to supplant me in Angelica's Heart; you know I live but in her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: I know your Love, and the only thing I like in you: She's a Virtuous Lady, and her Fortune's large; 'tis base, and most unfit my Brother's Years, to become your Rival.
Ah, Sir! if my Master loses her, I dare swear it will break his Heart. In my Conscience, I believe it is Love keeps him awake, and puts Gaming into his Head.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: Well, Son, if you obtain her, I'll forgive your Faults, and pay your Debts once more.
Sir, I don't doubt it; but I'm a little out of Mo∣ney at present.
Humph!
Money, Sir, is an Ingredient absolutely necessa∣ry in a Lover: A Hundred Guineas would accomplish my Desig
As I guess'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: At your old Trick again —No, no; I have been so often consen'd with your fair Promises.
Try me this time; lend me but Fifty.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: No.
Twenty.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: No.
Ten.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: No.
Hard-hearted Jew.
Five, Sir; for I can't go without some Money.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: Not a Sowse from me.
One, Sir, that we may dine; for I am sure my Master has not a Groat, by his Humility.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: No; if you are hungry, go fling a merry Main for your Dinner.
Ah, Sir, I never was so well bred: Besides, I hate trusting to Chance for my Food.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: I admire you have liv'd so long with your Ma∣ster. Then, Look'ee, Valere, get you to Angelica: Out with your Uncle, and you shan't want Money. In the mean time, Sirrah, do you get me a List of his Debts.
Yes, Sir. There's some hopes I may come in for my Wages.Aside.
Sir, I obey you in every thing— and fly to An∣gelica. Hearkee, Rascal, get me some Money, or I will cut your Ears off.Aside to Hector.Exit.
Money! Mercy on me; where shall I get it? Well, I think I am bewitch'd to him.Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: If I can but reclaim my Child, and match him to Angelica, I shall date the happiest part of my Life from this Moment.
Sir, your most humble Servant; is not you Name lere?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: It is, Sir.
Sir, I come to offer you my best Service.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: In what, pray, Sir?
Sir, I am Master of all sorts of Games, and live by that noble Art. My Name is Cogdie, call'd by some Count Cogdie.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: He takes me for my Son; I'll humour it, and hear what the Rogue has to say. Aside. Well, Sir, what then?
Hearing of your ill Fortune at Play, I came out of pure Generosity to teach you the management of the Die.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: The Management of the Die: why, is that to be taught?

Oh! aye, Sir; to learn to Cog a Die nicely re∣quires as good a Genius, as the Study of the Mathematicks. Now, Sir, here's your true Dice, a Man seldom gets any thing by them: Here's your false, Sir, hey, how they run. Now, Sir, these we generally call Doctors.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: The Consumption rather. Mercy upon me! what is our World come to?Aside.
Come, throw a Main, Sir, then Ill instruct you how to nick it; he is very dull. I tell you, Sir, in this Age, 'tis necessary that Children learn to play before they learn to read.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: I tell you, Sir, that I am amaz'd the Govern∣ment never preferr'd you to the Pillory for your wondrous Skill.
I find his ill Fortune has put him horridly out of Humour: I say again, that learning to play is of more use, than Fa, La, Mi, Sol, or cutting a Caper.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: I'll Fa, La, Caper, you Dog, know I am his Father, and hate gaming, and all such Rascals as you are. But stay, I'll pay you your Wages for the care you took of my Son.
Sir, your humble Servant, Sir, not a Penny, Sir.
No, Sir, a Cane.
Not in the least, Sir: I, I, I would not give you the trouble by no means, Sir. What a Sot was I, to mistake the Father for the Son.Exit running.
Oh, Sir! undone! undone! undone!
Undone! When wert thou otherwise?
Ah, Sir, but my Master, my Master—
What of him? Surely he was given me for a Curse.

Ah, Sir! as my Master was just stepping into Ange∣lica's Lodgings, so nicely drest; his Wigg, I believe, had a pound of Hair, and two pound of Powder in't; he look'd so pretty, that had she but seen him, she must have lov'd him, though her Heart had been made of Brass: But just as he was stepping in—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: She order'd her Footman to shut the Door upon him, I suppose, hearing his continued Extrava∣gance.
No, no, Sir, worse than that; a slovenly filthy Fellow whipt his Sword from his Side, whilst another, as bluff as a Midnight Constable, slapt him on the Back with an Action of forty Pounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: Ha! and did Angelica see it?
No, no, Sir, we being cunning, wheedled 'em to the Tavern; and 'tis but giving 'em a lusty Bottle, Sir, and I warrant we get it off for ten Guineas.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: How's this, an Action of forty Pounds got off for ten Guineas? I suspect a Trick——Come, show me the way to this Tavern.
What shall I do now? Sir, I, I, I came in such haste that I never thought to look up at the Sign.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: Then you are likely to carry the Money, Sirrah. Sirrah, this Sham won't take; the next time, Rascal, lay your Lyes closer, Rogue.Slaps him.Exit.
Ah, Hector, Hector! thou art no good Plotter. Well, I draw this Comfort from it however, I shall never dread the Gallows for Plotting.
Well, I have over-heard all; I thought what your Projects wou'd come to.
Why, Sir, the wisest Men sometimes fail; and you must own, that I study as hard as a starving Poet for your Interest: But if my Plots, like their Poetry, miscar∣ry, 'tis no fault of mine.
You'll still be witty out of Season; but prithee what's to be done now?
Oh, Sir! yonder goes Mrs. Security, who lent you once a hundred Guineas upon your Diamond Ring that you lost at play.

I remember I gave her fifty for the use of it: But, however call her in this Extremity, and bring up a Bottle of Sa with you. Exit Hector. Now for the Art of Perswasion to squeeze this old Spunge of fifty Guineas, that may make me Master of a Thousand before Night.
Mrs. Security, good Morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Secu.
SP.P: Mr. Valere, your very humble Servant.
A Chair there, quickly. Mrs. Security, let us renew our old Acquaintance, and cement it with a Glass of Sack.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Secu.
SP.P: Oh, dear Mr. Valere! I never drink in a Morning.
What, not a Glass of Sack? Come, Hector, fill. My Service to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Secu.
SP.P: Pray, young Man, give me but a little.
Fill it up, I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Secu.
SP.P: Oh, dear Sir! your Health.Drinks half.
What, my Health by halves? I'll not bait you a drop.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Secu.
SP.P: Well, I profess it will be too strong for me.
Hector, does not Mrs. Security look very handsom?
Truly, Sir, I think she grows younger and younger.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Secu.
SP.P: Away, you make me blush.
Ah! she'll have another Husband, I see by those Roguish Eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Secu.
SP.P: Fie, fie, Mr. Hector; these Eyes have done nothing but went since my good Husband, Zekiel Security, dyed; and the more because he dyed suddenly.Weeps.
Suddenly! Good lack! good lack! It e'en makes me weep to think on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Secu.
SP.P: He dyed in his Vocation, just sealing of a Bond.
Ah! wou'd thou wert with him, so I had a little of thy Money. Aside. Hector, fill t'other Glass to Mrs. Se∣curity to wash away Sorrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Secu.
SP.P: Oh! dear Sir, I thank you for your Civili∣ty; and you shall find me always ready to serve you.
I do believe you, Mrs. Security, and have occasion to your Kindness.
Ay, my Master pitch'd upon you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Secu.
SP.P: He knows he may command me.
I wou'd borrow fifty Guineas, Mrs. Security, which shall be repaid.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Secu.
SP.P: I don't doubt it, Sir, in the least; for you know my way —A Pledge—If it be not quite double the value, I won't stand with a Friend: And it shall be as safe as my Eyes, that I assure you.
Humph!
Ah, Duce on't, here's the Sack lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Secu.
SP.P: You had your Ring again, Mr. Valere: And I hope you don't mistrust me now.
Mistrust you! No, no, Madam. Hector, fetch Mrs. Security a Pledge.
A Pledge, Sir? Bless me! What does he mean now? A Pen and Ink, Sir?
Ay, ay, Mrs. Security shall have my Note.
As good as any Pledge in England.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Secu.
SP.P: It may be so—But I promised good Ze∣kiel to be wary of the Money he left me: Yea, and I will be very wary.
And very wicked—
Refuse my Note! I scorn your Money.
I'd have you to know, my Master's Note is as good as a Bankers — sometimes, when the Dice run well.Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Secu.
SP.P: Nay, if you are angry for my fair dealing, good morrow to you.

Oh, Impudence! she calls Cent. per Cent. fair deal∣ing—Go thy ways, but take my Curse along with thee. May some Town-Sharper perswade that Sanctify'd Face into Matrimony, and in one Night empty all thy Bags at Hazard.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Secu.
SP.P: Your Wishes hurt not me, ill-manner'd Fel∣low. I'd have you to know, if I wou'd marry again, I cou'd have a—
Nay, nay, Mistress, if we must have none of your Money, let's have none of your Impertinence.
Be gone, be gone, Woman, be gone.Pushes her off.

Oh! deep Reflection— wou'd I cou'd avoid thee: To become the Scoff of Mercenary Wretches— And, thro' my own mismanagement, reduc'd to base Ne∣cessity. Oh, Angelica! I'll cast a real Penitent beneath thy Feet.

Q.L: And if once more thy Pardon I obtain,
Love in my Heart shall the sole Monarch reign.

SP.P: AFter all his solemn Promises to quit that scan∣dalous Vice, when he can hold my Love upon no other Terms, does he still pursue that certain Ruine to his Fame and Fortune? But I resolve to banish him my Heart, which he has justly lost by his perfidious Dealing. I feel, I feel my Liberty return; and I charge thee, Favourite, speak of him no more.
No. no, Madam, fear not me; I hate him for your sake, Madam: Was he like his Uncle, there's the Man for my Money.
Because you have a large share of his, I suppose: Old Men must bribe high. Name neither to me, I hate Mankind.Exit Favourite.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Weal.
SP.P: Well said, Sister; I hate Mankind too, and yet the Fellows will follow me; but who is the Man that has put you out of conceit with the whole Sex, Valere?
The same; no other had ever power to shock my quiet—Nor shall he; for this moment I'll rase him from my Thoughts.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Weal.
SP.P:
If she holds her Resolution, I am happy. aside. That Task may prove more difficult then you imagine,
Sister. Come, come, this is a flight of sudden Passion, that would fall upon the sight of Valere.
You mistake, Sister, my Resentment is grounded upon Reason.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Weal.
SP.P: I know he has given you Cause enough: But Love is blind; had a Man used me so, I shou'd have su∣spected his Reality sooner.
Why, do you think he loves me not?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Weal.
SP.P: It looks with such a Face—
Why then did he take pains to be reconcil'd?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Weal.
SP.P: Gallantry, mere Gallantry; and she that can∣not distinguish, often mistakes it for a real Amour. Ah, Angelica! you are but a Novice yet, and don't understand the Beau-Mond. A VVoman shou'd always speak more than she thinks, and think more than she writes, or she'll ne're be upon the square with Men.
I shall neither write nor speak to any of 'em for the future, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Weal.
SP.P: And do you positively think you cou'd resist Valere, if he should come in this Minute?
I do, positively.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Weal.
SP.P: What, in his most moving Air? for you know he is Master of a false insinuating Tongue: Shou'd he, I say, throw himself at your Feet in a Tone of Tragedy; cry, forgive me, Angelica, or kill me if you please; I'll not oppose the Blow, nor strive to save my Life by one poor VVord—I love you, and only you: Does not your Soul tell you so in my behalf? VVill you not answer me? Then rising from his Knees, VVill then, says he, nothing but my Death wipe out my Fault? Give it me then, cruel Fair; for now to live is Pain. If I have lost you, I have lost all that's worth my Care. Then of∣fers to draw his Sword: At sight of which you are melted into Pity, and once again betray'd. Is not this true, An∣gelica? Ha, ha, ha.
I confess I have too often been deceiv'd— but now he shall find I am upon my guard— and were he the on∣ly one remaining of his Sex, I wou'd not— if I know my heart— Marry him.
I'm pleas'd to hear your Resolution; and doubly pleas'd to find you Mistress of your Passion— 'tis a point of Wisdom to Casheire such follies as blind our Sense, and make our Judgments err.
'Tis very true.
Believe me Sister— I had rather see you Mar∣ried to Age, Avarice, or a Fool— then to Valere — for can there be a greater Misfortune than to Marry a Gamester?
I know 'tis the high road to Beggery.
And your Fortune being all ready Money will be thrown off with Expedition— were it as mine is in∣deed— but are you sure your Heart is disengag'd?
Why, do you doubt it?
I have a reason, Sister, that when you have sa∣tisfy'd me you shall know.
Then be satisfy'd— I will never see him more— now the secret.
Why, then know I love him.
How! You!
Yes, I, where's the Wonder?
You that advis'd against the Gamester.
That was for your good, Sister—Our Cir∣cumstances are different— My Estate's Intail'd enough to supply his Riots, and why should I not bestow it upon the Man I like?

What in that Mourning Weed resolv'd on Matrimo∣ny, and is your Lord forgot already— did I take such pains in rubbing your Temples, whilst Favourite apply'd the Harts-horn to your Nose, when the fainting Fits came thicker and thicker, and was it all but Affectation—And does your dead Husband's Picture that dangles at your Watch there, serve only to put you in mind of another?
And where's the Crime— I lov'd him living as much as any Wife, or rather more. And did what De∣cency required when he died— but being free, I'm free to chose.
Then who so fit as Lovewell for your choice, whose honourable Love has long pursu'd you.
You are not to direct my Inclinations.
Nor you mine— Favourite, Enter Favourite if Valere comes, I will see him—that good you have done, Sister.
See him, Madam!
Yes, Impertinence.Ex. Fav.

Ay, see him, if thou wilt, but to little pur∣pose— I doubt not his return, when once he finds En∣couragement, 'tis his awe has kept him Silent, not that I care much for him neither; but it is the greatest Mortifi∣cation in Nature to see a handsome Fellow make Love to another before ones Face.Enter Footman.
Madam, the Marquess of Hazard to wait on your Honour.
Pugh, that Fool.Enter Marquess

Hey, let my three Footmen wait with my Chair there— the Rascals have come such a high Trot— they've jolted me worse than a Hackney Coach— and I'm in as much disorder— as if I had not been drest to Day— pardon me, Madam, I took the Liberty to adjust my self, e're I approach'd you.
You are the exact Model of Dress— but Monsieur Mareque, methinks you are grown perfect in our Tongue.

The value I have for the English Ladies, made me take particular pains in the Study— duce on't, I shall be discover'd, if I forget my French tone— Ah, Madam, Vous parles Francois Mienque I parlez l'enlais.
Ah, Ponit de ton't Monsuire.
But there's no Language like the Eyes, Madam— and yours would set the World on Fire.
Oh, Gallant.

DIV1.HEAD: A Song, Sung to the VVidow.
DIV1.L: IN vain you sable Weeds put on,
Clowds cannot long Eclips the Sun;
Nature has plac'd you in a Sphere,
To give us Day-light all the Year;
'Tis well for those
Of Cupid's Foes,
That your Beauties thus shrowded lye;
For when that Night
Puts on the Light,
What Crowds of Martyr'd Slaves will dye.

DIV1.HEAD: A Song, Sung to the Gamester, when he has won Money.

LG.L: FAIR Caelia, she is Nice and Coy,
While she hold the Lucky Lure;
Her Repartees are Pish and Fye,
And you in vain persue her.
Stay but till her Hand be out,
And she become your Debtor;
Address her then, and without doubt,
You'll speed a great deal Better.
'Tis the only way
When she has lost at Play,
To purchase the courted Favour,
Forgive the Score,
And offer her more,
I'll lay my Life you have her.

SP.P: I had lik'd to have fought last Night, for asser∣ting your Prerogative of Beauty.
With whom, pray?
With Valere, whose continual Toast was your Si∣ster: I must confess it has given me a passionate Desire of seeing her, that I may hereafter with greater Assurance main∣tain your Cause.
What would the Fellow have me Introduce him— My Cause don't want your Sword.
She's Jealous already, if my Footmen observe my Orders, she'll secure me here for fear of losing the Prize.
This Fool's doubly my Aversion— now he has nam'd my Sister, would I were rid of him.
Has your Ladyship play'd at Court this Winter?
In my Weed?
I ask your pardon, Madam, but that Beauty and Gayety nothing can Eclipse, who can look on you, and mind your Dress?
That's well enough exprest— but nothing, that he says, can please me now.
A Footman in Green, Monsieur waits for an An∣swer.Ex. Footman.
Is this a time? let him wait at the Chocolate∣House at St. James's an hour hence— Oh, Madam, did you know how I languish for you!
When did I give you leave to make a Decla∣ration of you Love— Monsieur— pray, read your Letter, and give the Lady an Answer.
I confess it comes from a Lady— but if—
My Lady Gamewell has sent three times for you, and will not begin to play till you come.
Alez Vous En Cocquin— Let her stay.Ex Footm.
Insolence! What does the Fellow mean?
'Tis the greatest Fatigue in Nature to hold a Cor∣respondence with Impertinence— but your Ladiship is the Reverse of—Enter another Footman.
Sir, the Lady Amorous begs the Honour of your Company this Minute, Sir Credulous is just gone out of Town.
La diable t' omport— Out of my sight— Am I not Engag'd?
Engag'd? Upon my Word you are not— What House is the place you Appoint to receive your Assignati∣ons in—

No, upon my Honour, Madam— but I presume they have search'd the whole Town— and seeing my Equi∣page at your Door, were so audacious to send in their Mes∣sage— but I'le turn away my Footmen for this Embarisment▪

Pray, let not my House be distinguish'd by you, not your Equipage, for the future— I am not to be us'd so, angerly Now, for a set and grave face to put me- Ent. Love∣well. more out of humour, if possible—
You seem in disorder, Madam—
Who can be otherwise, when People take liberty beyond the bounds of good manners—
Who dares in my Lady Wealthy's house.
Upon my Sol, Sir, she takes it quite wrong— Or she's— confoundedly Jealous.
Sir, I am positive that Lady cannot be in the wrong: And read it in her Looks, your Absence wou'd please her—
Sir—
No words here, Sir — If you wou'd dispute it, I'le meet you when, and where you please—
Your most humble Servant— In a low Voice. You shall hear from me— He, hey, who's there?— My Ser∣vants— Madam, as your Ladyship said, I'm not to be us'd thus—Exit.
Monsieur— He's gone, I wou'd not lose the Fop neither—
Gone, Madam! so you wou'd have him, I suppose:

You suppose! how dare you suppose my Thoughts— and who gave you this Priviledge in my
House? Shortly I shall be wish'd Joy; for this is a Preroga∣tive above a Depending Lover—
I plead no merit; and my long successless Love assures me I have no power— but I understood—
You understood! Ay, you always understand wrong, Mr. Lovewell.

I do confess I wander in the Mazes— and still pursue a brightness which I cannot fix— To please you has been my long and only study; Witness the many Years of awful Servitude I paid your Virgin-beauty, and the pains I felt, when I beheld you Wedded to another: I cou'd not bear the sight, but in a cruel Banishment past my unlucky hours, 'till Fate, in pitty, set you free, but all in vain, for still my Portion is Despair.
Nay, if you are running into that grave Stuff— I must leave you, tho' in my own House— for I have got the Spleen intollerably, and cannot endure it.
No, Madam, I'le retire— I Love too much to dis∣obey— only when you reflect on your admiring Slaves, think on my Fidelity.Exit.

Thou art a poor constant fool, that's the truth o'nt,— and thou hast merit too, I'le say that for thee— but we Women don't always mind that— Enter Valere. Here comes the present Ascendant of my Heart—
Ha, the Widow here— now cou'd I make her my Friend now, for a serious Face— and an Heroick Stile— Madam, — —
— Sir—

My Stars shed their kindest Influence to Day, and blest me with the Opportunity of finding you alone— Pit∣ty is Essential to the Fair, and ought to be extended to those that sink beneath the rigour of their Chains—
'Tis the diversion of your Sex to complain, I believe Mr. Valere finds few barbarous in ours—
None more unfortunate in Love than I, and tho' my heart is breaking, I'm forbid to tell my pain.
I hope 'tis to my Wish— It may be me he means, else why this Address— She must be very Cruel, that lets you sigh without return— Is it in my power to assist you—
Oh, Madam, All, All's in your power— You rule my Fate.
Then you shall be happy— 'tis so—
On my knees let me receive the Confirmation of your Promise— and seal it here—
Ha! kneeling to my Sister, faithless Man—
There, Madam, there's the angry Brow, that darts Distraction to my peace: Your Aid to clear that Storm is what I su'd for—
Insufferable ill Breeding—
Oh, Angelica! I cast me at your Feet.
No, back to my Sisters, there I found you.
Only to Intercede to you—
False, by my Honour, he was making violent Love— I'le teize her, however.
Making Love; what does she mean?
And you receiv'd it, I suppose.
You Interrupted me, e're I cou'd give my An∣swer.—
Why, Madam, my design you know—.
Yes, yes, Mr. Valere, I know your design— I have not had so many Sighing, Dying Lovers, but I can guess their design—
But mine was—
Oh, fy, do'nt declare it here— You know my Sister has a Passion for you— and I wou'd not Ty∣rannize—
'Tis not in your Power—
Oh, the Devil— Madam, I own 'tis an Offence to a Lady of your Beauty and Merit, to make a Declaration of Love—
Not at all, Sir— when one likes the Person— I'le— consider on't— but, harkee, do not deceive my Sister too far, it may be dangerous—
It's not in your Power—or his, to deceive me, I see thro' your shallow Artifices, and despise it—
Those that rely upon their own Judgment are soonest caught, Sister— remember, I have given you fair warning—Exit
I'm in amaze—

You need not— I know my Sister's design— but that's not my Quarrel to you— Quarrel, did I say? No, I am grown to a perfect State of indifference— Quarrels may be reconciled— but a Man that basely breaks his Word, and forfeits Faith and Honour, is not worth our Anger, but deserves to be despis'd
I do confess I am a Wretch below your scorn, I own my Faults, and have no refuge but your Mercy—
In the old strain agen—
If you abandon me, I'm lost for ever— for you, and only you, are Mistress of my Fate.
Your daily Actions contradict your Words— and shows I have no such Power in your Heart— did you not promise, nay, swear, you'd never Game agen—

I did, and for the perjur'd Crime, Merit your end∣less hate; but you, in pity, may forgive me— Oh, Angelica, see at your Feet an humble Penitent kneel, who, if not by your Goodness rais'd— will grow for ever to his Native Soil.
You wou'd be Pardon'd only to Offend agen.
Never, never— here on this Beauteous Hand I swear, whose touch runs thrilling thro' my Heart— and by those lovely Eyes that dart their fire into my Soul, never to dis∣oblige you more.
That Oath hath done the Business, I see by her looks

Rise Valere— I differ from my Sex in this, I wou'd not change where once I've given my Heart, if possible— therefore resolve to make this last Tryal— banish your Love for Play, and rest secur'd of mine.
Oh, transport! let me kiss those soft forgiving Lips, the Memory of whose sweetness shall Arm me against Temp∣tation.
So— now my old Man may go hang himself.aside.

Cou'd you but know the anxious pains I felt, the Jealous racking Cares that prey'd upon my Soul— When I heard my Uncle was allow'd to tell his Suit— you'd then have found how dear Valere had priz'd you.
What I did was to revenge your falshood— tho' Love's my Witness, Dorante's my Aversion— and let this present shew who 'tis that Reigns Triumphant in my Heart.
Your Picture! Oh, give it me, that in the absence of the dear Original— I may Feast my Eyes on that.

But mark, Valere, the Injunction I shall lay, whilst you keep safe this Picture, my Heart is yours— but if thro' Avarice, Carelesness, or Falshood, you ever part with it, you lose me from that moment.
I agree; And when I do, kissing it except to your self, may all the Curses, ank'd with your Disdain, pursue me— This, when I look on't, will Correct my folly, and strike a sacred awe upon my Action—
'Tis worth Two hundred Pounds, a good Move∣able, when Cash runs low—ide.
Well, I am convinc'd, let a Woman make wha Re∣solutions she will, when alone— the sight of her Lover will break 'em.
Madam, Mr. Dorante is coming up.
I'le not be seen, adieu.Exit.

My charming Love, adieu— take care to w your Benefactor Mrs. Favorite; he's a Lover ipe w ¦cretion,
ha, ha, ha. Enter Dorante your Ser∣vant Uncle, ha, ha, ha—

STAGE.HI: holds up the Picture to the Nose.

SP.P: This young Rake's presence bodes me no good, I fear. Mrs. Favourite your Servant— Is your Lady to be spoke with.
I doubt not, Sir,— I don't know what she is— I'm sure I'm almost wild; our Business is all spoil'd— Valere is reconcil'd agen.
Ah, that insinuating young Dog.
She has just now given him her Picture set round with Diamonds.
I thought, indeed, something sparkled in my Eyes— But what's to be done?

I know not— he has promis'd her to Play no more, if he keeps his Word we have no hopes; but if he breaks it, as I doubt not but he will, Pride and Revenge may work her to our Ends— You may be certain, Sir, I'le let slip no Opportunity to serve you.
I do believe it— and to encourage you to believe me grateful— Accept of this Ring.
Oh, dear Sir, you are too Generous— I don't me∣rit it— Pray, Excuse me—
Nay, I will not be deny'd.
Well, Sir, since you will have it so— I'le not fail to move your Suit— I'le do my best Endeavours, I'le assure you; write, Sir, write, and I'le deliver the Let∣ter— then let me alone to back it.
You must urge the largeness of my Fortune— the staidness of my Temper, and withall tell her, I am not a∣bove two and Fourty— I was Grey at Thirty.
I warrant you, Sir,— Besure you Exclaim against your Nephew's Gaming.
Ay, ay, I'le go write it this moment— and send it presently.
I'le be in the way to receive it.

DIV3.HEAD: Scene changes to Sir Thomas Valere's House.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir Tho. and Hector, with several Papers.

SP.P: Sir, I have brought you a compleat Account of the Debts of my Master— I think I have not forgot one Farthing; for, if I mistake not, you desir'd to know 'em all, Sir—
Ay, ay, come read 'em over.

That I will, Sir, in two words— A true List of the Debts of Mr. James Valere, which was by him Contra∣cted within the City of London, and Liberty of Westmin∣ster, which his Father Sir Thomas Valere has promised to Discharge.
If I discharge them, or not, is not your busi∣ness— Go on—
'Tis my design, Sir,— In the first place, then— Item, due to Richard Scrape Fifty five Pounds, Nine Shillings, and Ten Pence Half-penny— for Five Years Wages— and Money disburs'd for Necessaries.
Richard Scrape, who's he?
Your most humble Servant, Sir—Bows.
You, why, is not your Name Hector?
Ay, Sir, that is my Name de Novo— My Master thought Richard sounded too clumsy for a Gentleman's Va∣let, and a Gamster— so, Sir, he gave me the Name of Hector from the Knave of Diamonds.
A very pretty Name— I admire he don't call his Mistress Pallas from the Queen of Spades— but, how came you so rich, Sirrah, to be able to lend your Master Money?
Why, when the Dice has run well, my Master wou'd now and then tip me a Guinea, Sir.
And so you supply'd him, when he wanted, with his own Money: Oh, Extravagance—
'Tis what many an honest Gentleman is drove to somes, Sir.
More shame for 'em— Go on—
Secondly. Sir, here is due to Jeremy Aron, Usurer by Profession— And Jew by Religion.
Never trouble your self about that, I shall pay no Usuer's Debts, I assure you.
Then, Sir, here is two hundred Guinea's lost to my Lord Lovegame, upon Honour.
That's another Debt I shall not Pay.

How, not pay it, Sir— why, Sir, among Gen∣tlemen, that Debt is look'd upon the most just of any: You may cheat Widows, Orphans, Tradesmen without a Blush— but a Debt of Honour, Sir, must be paid— I cou'd name you some Noblemen that pays no Body— yet a Debt of Honour, Sir, is as sure as their ready Money.
He that makes no Conscience of wronging the Man— whose Goods have been deliver'd for his use, can have no pretence to Honour— whatever Title he may wear — But to the next.
Here is the Tayler's Bill— the Milliner's, Hosier's, Shoemaker's, Tavern, and Eating House, in all, 300 l.
A fine Sum, truly.

Ah, Sir, I have not nam'd the Barber, Perriwig-ma∣ker and Persumer, which is 100 l. more— besides, he is in Arrears to Madamoiselle Margret De la Plant, lately ar∣riv'd from France, with whom he Covenanted for four Guinea's a Week.
For four Guinea's a Week, for what?
Oh, Sir, pardon me there, I never betray the Se∣crets of my Master.—
Four Guinea's a Week.—
Ay, Sir, and very cheap— considering he made his Bargain in the Winter— and truly I don't know but the Wo∣man lost by it.
You don't— take that, Sirrah— you shan't lose by it, however— go, Rascal, pay your Whores and Debts of Honour out of that.
Ay, Sir, they'll never take this Money of me: if you please, Sir, I'll send 'em to your Levee, and you may pay 'em your self.

Sirrah, I shall break your Head—go get you to the Rake, your Master; play, hang, or starve together, I care not— Debts, with a Pox; Gaming, Drinking, Wench∣ing, rare Debts to bring into a Court of Chancery— you, I. I. I. I. I — bring me such a Bill of Debts, Rogue, mercy on me, that there can be such Impudence in the World—Oh, oh. I have much ado to forbear thee— me such a Bill of Debts—Exit.
So our Affairs goes backwards, I find honest Richard, patient, I say, go seek thy Master out.

Q.L: Fortune may change, and give a lucky Main;
And what undid us, set us up again.

DIV3.TRAILER: The End of the Second ACT.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT the Third.

SP.P: WHere can my Master be now—I shou'd suspect he were at play — but that I know, he has no Money—sure this old Dad of his will open his Purse Strings once more, if he is reconcil'd to Angelica; I long to know what success he meets with—oh, here he comes—
SP.STAGE: Enter Valere with his Hat under his Arm, full of Money, he counting it—
SP.P: I waited on your Father, according to Order, Sir, with a List of your Debts— and the generous old Gentleman — I thank him, gave me more than I expected— hey-day, he minds me not— ah, I doubt we are all untwisted— no hopes of Angelica—
Five hundred fifty seven Guinea's and an half.
Ha! what do I see! the Plate Fleet's arriv'd — by what miracle fell these Galleons into our power— I hope, Sir, since Fortune has been so kind—
A Curse of Ill-luck— stamps had I but held in the last hand, I shou'd have had 300 Guinea's more of my Lord Duke's— besides what I Betted.Walks about.
I am over-joy'd, Sir, at your good Fortune— but as I was saying, Sir—
But hold, my Lord Lovegame owes me 200 upon Honour; 'tis pretty well— I have not made an ill Morn∣ing's work on't.
There's no speaking to him—
Ah! there's no Musick like the chink of Gold— by Jove this Sound is sweeter in my Ear— than all the Margaretta's in Europe— Ha! Hector, where come you from Sirrah?
Came, Sir— Why I was here before you— but For∣tune's Golden mist Conceal'd me from your Sight— Sir, I Congratulate your good Success— but how—

Ay, 'tis Success, indeed, if thou knowst all— Ho∣nest Jack Sharper lent me Five Guinea's, that I shou'd pay him Ten if luck run on my side. I have discharg'd my promise, and brought off a Thousand clear.
Huzza— Why, you are a made Man!
And we meet again at Five, where I design to win a Thousand more, Boy.
Ay, but if you shou'd lose all back, Sir.
Impossible, this is a lucky day— Angelica and I am reconciled— my Faults forgiven, and all my wishes Crown'd, Hector—Shewing the Picture

Bless my Eye-sight— A Picture set with Dia∣monds— nay, then Hector chear up— for now the bad times will mend, Sings why now a Fig for your Fathr's kindness, you are able to pay your Debts your self, Sir—
A Pox on thee for naming 'em— thou hast given me the Spleen— pay my Debts, quotha— the bare Word is enough to turn all my luck.
Say you so, Sir! is paying Debts unlu
Ay, certainly, the most unlucky thing

Humph— I now find the reason why Quality hate to pay their Debts— A duce on't, I wish I had known as much this Morning, I wou'd not have paid the Cobler for Heel-peiceing my Shoes— for ought I know it may be a Guinea out of my Way, for my Master does not use to be so slow— Sir, now you are in Stock, Sir, if you please to put my Wages into my Hands— it shall be ve∣ry safe in Bank against you want it.
The Divel's in the Fellow— speak one word more of paying Debts, Sirrah— and I'll cut your Ears off— I shall have no occasion to Borrow— and my Father will pay your Debt amongst the rest—
He won't pay a Soue, Sir— he broke my Head at the very sight of the List—
Ay, that was in his Passion— there's a Plaister for that Wound—Gives him a Guinea

Sir, your most humble Servant—I find we mid∣ling People are out of the Quality's Latitude— pay∣ing Debts are only unlucky to Gentlemen— Sir, pray, Sir, give me leave to offer one thing to your serious Con∣sideration.
I Bar Debts—
Not a word of that, Sir.
Out with it then.
That you'd lay by 500 l. of that Money against a Rainy Day.
But suppose I shou'd have more Set me than I can Answer.—
'Tis but sending for it, at worst, Sir.
So baulk my Hand in the mean time— and lose the winning of a Thousand— No, no, there's nothing like ready Money to nick Fortune.
Ah, Sir, but you know she has often Jilted you; and wou'd it not be better to have a little Pocket Money secure— put by but 200, Sir.
Well, I consider on't— ha! see who knocks.
A Dun, I warrant.
I have not a Farthing of Money, remember that Sirrah.—Puts up his Money hastily
Lying is a Thriving Vocation.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Galloon a Tayler, and Mrs. Topknot a Milliner.

SP.P: Ha! Good Morrow to you—Good Morrow to you Mrs. Topknot; Mrs. Topknot you are a great Stranger, Why don't you call and see me sometimes?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Topk.
SP.P: Indeed, Sir, I call very often —tho' I have not had the good fortune to see you—for you was still a∣sleep, or gone abroad.
I am sorry it fell out so; well, have you brought your Bill?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Topk.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, Gives him her Bill I hope you lik'd your last Linnen Sir.
Very well.
Sir, I beg the Favour of you—
I must not let two fasten upon him at once — Mr. Galloon a word with you—you always make my Cloaths too little for me.
I am sorry for that.
My Breeches are Seam-rent in Three or Four places.
I'll take care——
You Sew most abominably slight.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Topk.
SP.P: We are about Marrying our Daughter.
I hope you have provided a good Match; for she is very handsome, Faith.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Topk.
SP.P: The Girl is not despiseable—the Man is very well to pass in the World, but the small Fortune we de∣sign for her, must be paid down upon the Nail—therefore, Sir, I intreat you to help me to my Money, if possible.
If it was possible, I wou'd, Mrs. Topknot; and am heartily sorry that it is not in my power.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Top.
SP.P: It is a Debt of a long standing, Mr. Valere, and I must not be said nay.
I know it is; but upon honour I can't pay you now.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Top.
SP.P: Let me have some, if you can't pay me All — Ten Guinea's at present wou'd do me singular service.
May I sink if I have seen Five these Six Months.
That he has not to my knowledge.
Pray, Sir, consider me, if it be never so small; my Wife is ready to Lye in-and Coals are very dear-and Journey mens Wages must be paid.
Why, the Devil is in the Fellow! Wou'd you have a Man pay what he has not?—What business had you to get Chil∣dren, without you had Cabbage enough to maintain 'em?
Hector — No Invention?Aside to Hector.
When will you be pleas'd that I shall call agen, Sir?
When you please.
Ill call to morrow, Sir.
With all my heart.
Do you think, Sir, you can let me have some if I come?
Not that I know of.
No, nor I neither—Hark ye, when he has Money I'll bring you word.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Top.
SP.P: Don't tell me, I won't go out of the House with∣out Money.
With all my heart—Hector! No Stratagem to save me from these Leaches?Aside to Hector.
Then you must e'en lye with my Master or me; for here are no spare Beds—Let me advise you to make no noise, you'll have your Money sooner than you think for— your Ear —Whispers.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Top.
SP.P: To be Married say you?
And to Madam Angelica the great Fortune?
The same.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs Top.
SP.P: I wish you Joy Sir—Pray recommend me to your Lady, for Gloves, Fans and Ribbons.
I hope, Sir, I shall have the Honour to make your Wedding Suit
That you shall, I promise you;— The Rogue has hit on't.Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Top
SP.P: But will this Match be speedy, Sir?
I hope so.
To Morrow, Sir?
Or next day—but we must intreat your absence at present—for my Master expects his Father with the Lady's Trustees, in order to settle the Affair—and if you are seen, it may spoil the business.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Top.
SP.P: Well, well, well, I go, I go,—Runs a little way, and turns You'll put your Master in mind of me?
Ay, ay.
And me too pray.
I'll do your business I'll warrant you, Go, go, go,— begon, begon, begon,—Pushes 'em out—There Sir, I have brought you off once more: Here's two or three Days re∣spite however.

Why then there's two or three Days of Peace—for these are the most disagreeable Companions a Gentleman can meet with. — I Dine at the Rummer, where you'll find me if you want me. I promis'd to visit Angelica again to Night, but fear I shall break my Word.
And will you prefer Play before that Charming Lady?
Not before her—but I have given my parole to some Men of Quality, and I can't in Honour disappoint 'em.

Ah, What a Juglers Box is this word Honour! It is a kind of a Knight of the Post—that will Swear on either side for Interest I find—But, Sir, had you not better make sure work on't; Marry the Lady whilst she's in the mind, least Fortune wheel about and throw you back again.
Marry her, say'st thou—I am not resolved if I shall Marry or not.
High-day! Why I thought it had been what you de∣sired above all things—But I find your Pocket and your Heart still runs Counter.
No, Sirrah, I Love the Charming Maid as much as ever: Love her from my Soul—But then I love Liberty.
And what shou'd hinder you from enjoying it!

Ah, Hector, If I Marry her, I must forsake my dear divesion puing out a Box and Dice which to me is the very Soul of Living; — 'tis the gentilest way of passing ones time, every day produces something new.—Who is happier than a Gamester, who more respected, I mean those that make any Figure in the World? who more carest by Lords and Dukes? or whose Conversation more agreeable— whose Coach siner in the Ring - Or Finger in the side Box produce more Lustre— who has more Attendance from the Drawers, — or better Wine from the Master?—Or Nicer serv'd by the Cook. In short there is an Air of Magnificence in't,—a Gamester's hand is the Philosophers Stone that turns all it touches into Gold.
And Gold into nothing

A Gentleman that plays is admitted every where— Women of the strictest Vertue will Converse with him,— for Gaming is as much in fashion here as 'tis in France, and our Ladies look upon it, as the height of ill Breeding, not to have a Passion for play; Oh! the Charming Company of half a do∣zen Ladies, with each a Dish of Tea,—to behold their lan∣guishng Ogles with their Eyes, their Ravishing White Hand, to hear the delicious Scandal which they vent between each Sip, just piping hot from invention's Mint, wherein they spare none from the States-Man to the i—and damn Plays before they are Acted, especially if the Author be un∣known,— this ended, the Cards are call'd for.
And Open War proclaim'd—and every Cock boat proves a Privateer.
Our Engagements are not so Terrible,—with us revenge reaches no farther than the Pocket.
No more don't a Highway Man,—and yet the World thinks both Lives equally immoral.

None of your Similes Sirrah, do you hear? —Where is the immorality of Gaming,— now I think there can be nothing more Moral—It unites Men of all Ranks, — the Lord and the Peasant — the Haughty Dutchess and the City
Dame,—The Marquiss and the Foot man, all without distinction play together.

Q.L: And sure that Life can ne'er offensive prove,
That Teacheth Men such peaceful ways of Love.

SP.P: The Marquiss of Hazard Sir.—
The Marquiss of Hazard, what wants he!
Do you hear; do you wait with my Chair at the Corner of the Street, for I wou'd be Incognito.
What does he pretend to?
I presume, Sir, your Name is Valere.
I don't remember I ever had any other Sir.
Sir I shou'd take it as an extraordinary Favour, if you'll be pleas'd to Command the Absence of your Valet de Chambre.
Be gone.Exit Hector.
Now, Sir, do you know who I am?
I think, , I never had the Honour of your Acquain∣tance.

Allom Courage, push him home, he seems daunted already, Aside Sir, I have made the Tour of Europe, and have had the respect paid to me in all Courts, that became my Quality;—In Spain I kept Company with none but Arch-Dukes, in France with Princes of the Blood, — and since I have been here, I have had the Honour to Sup or Dine with most of the great People at Court.
Why so hot Sir?
And, Sir, my Person is not more known than my Va∣lour—I have fought a Hundred Duels, and never faild to kill or wound,—without receiving the least hurt my self.
You had very good luck truly Sir,—What does the Blockhead Aim at!Aside.
Sir, Fortune owes my Life protection, for sake of the Noble Race from whence I Sprung—my Father's Grand∣father's great Grand-father, was Vice Roy of Naples.
Oh! one may see that in your Air, Sir.

Now, Sir, there is a certain Lady that has a Passion for my Person, not that I am in Love with her: Only Gra∣titude,—and I am inform'd by her Woman, that you make your Addresses there; now, Sir, I suffer no Man be∣neath my Quality to mix his pretentions with mine.
The Ladies Name Sir?
The Lady Wealthy.
You are misinform'd upon my Word Sir; that Lady is at your service for me.
That declaration comes not from your Heart—your Encomiums on Angelica last Night, serv'd only to conceal your Love from me.
So far from that, I did not know you till you had left the Room.
Sir, I say you must not pretend to vye with Qua∣lity?
I know the distance Fortune has put between us Sir.
Then pray observe it, Sir;— don't think every Fel∣low we condescend to play with, fit Companions for us Men of Quality.
Cocking his HatFellow Sir—laying his Hand on his Sword
Yes, Fellow Sir—He has a Heart, I find, I'll mo∣derate my Passion.Aside.
You will have it then, I see.Draws.
No, upon my Word Sir, I was in jest all the while.
But I am in earnest, Sir—and therefore Draw—What, does the Courage of your Royal Ancestors, Vice Roys of Na∣ples fail you?
Sir, I made a Vow never to kill another Man,—and therefore pray put up, you have given me as much satis∣faction as I desir'd,—I thirst for no Revenge.
Sir, I am not to be trifled with, the Wine is drawn, and you shall drink.Slaps him.
Hy, what's the matter:lays hold of the Marquiss who draws.
Ha, Company! nay, then-Sir, this is too much to bear.
Hold, hold, Sir, hold, what do you do?
Let me go, let me go.
Ay, ay, prithee let him go, he is not so dangerous as thou imagin'st Hector — ha, ha, ha
Why then let him go,—there, Sir, I have done.
I shall find a time Sir.
To be kickd—you have been us'd too civilly here.

A time! for what, for what the Devil do you come into our Nation to Crow over us —I believe we shall find a time this Campaign to teach you better manners—your Ca∣pering Country are fitter for Dancing Masters than Soldiers ha, ha, ha.
It suits not with my Quality, to answer the imper∣tinency of a Valt—Monsieur Adie—previs Gard uns aut'ne fesExit.
Coxcomb below resentment,— looking on his Watch I have out-staid my time.

Q.L: Now Fortune be my Friend, I'll ask no more,
One lucky Hour may double all my sare.

P.HI: Or make you Bankrupt as you was before.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE Changes: Enter Lady Wealthy Sola.

STAGE.HI: A Tale, Pen Ink and Paper set out.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Weal.
SP.P:
Which way shall I contrive to disappoint my Si∣sters Wishes! now wou'd I give half my Estate to feed my Va∣nity. Oh, that I cou'd once bring Valere within my power, i'd—
use him as his ill breeding deserves; Id teach him to be parti∣cular. He has promis'd Angelica to play no more; I fancy that proceeds from his want of Money rather than Inclination— If I cou'd be sure of that—I'll try however. If my pro∣ject takes, I shall agen break their Union —and if I can't serve my Pride, I shall at least disturb their Peace; and either brings me Pleasure. Sits down and Writes Now how shall I convey this to his Hands—It is not proper to send any of my own Servants — Who's there?
Did your Ladyship call, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Weal.
SP.P: Ay, Get me a Porter.
A Porter! Madam, Robin, John, and Nicholas are all within.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Weal.
SP.P: And what then? Do as I bid you.
What can she want with a Porter! — I am re∣solv'd to watch.Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Weal.
SP.P: 'Tis better being confin'd to a Desart, where one never sees the Face of Man — than not to be admir'd by all Enter Porter Here, carry this to Mr. Valere, Do you know him?
Yes, and please your Honour, very well.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Weal.
SP.P: Go, bring me an Answer then.Exit.

Ha! Lovewell, I must avoid his presence, least he discover this Intrigue—he'll be alarm'd at the sight of a Porter in my Lodgings —besides, my Soul resents the ill Treatment I have given him—he indeed merits better usage—but I know not how, I cannot resolve on MatrimonyExit.

Gone! Am I then shun'd like Pestilential Air — yet doom'd to doat upon her cold indifference — Oh! give me Patience, or I burst with Rage —— there must be more than her bare temper in't—She Loves—ay, there's the Cause— Oh! the racking thought; by all the powers
it fires each vital part, and with a double warmth strikes every active sence.

Q.L: Hear me ye powers — And if you e'er design
To make this dear, this scornful Beauty mine,
Grant in the Lieu— I may my Rival meet,
And throw him gasping at his Lady's feet.Exit.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Angelica, and Favourite with a Letter in her Hand.

SP.P: I shall not open it indeed—— if you venture to receive Letters again, without my leave, I shall discharge you from your attendance, Mrs. Favourite.
I do it for your good, Madam.
For my good! Impertinence — Am I to be Go∣vern'd by those I may Command?
In spight of all that I can do, I shall lose my Sallary; for when he finds the Cause go backwards, he'll Fee no more.
So, he's here too, by your appointment, I suppose.
May I venture to approach the Rays of that Divi∣nity, which dart into my Soul an Impetuous Flame.
Oh dear, Sir, there's a Fire in the next Room, whose Flames will warm you better than my Beauty, I believe.
Well, really Madam, I think Valere cou'd not have exprest himself finer.
Cease your odious Comparisons —Mr. Dorante, might I advise you, Make your Addresses to my Woman — I'm sure you'll meet a kind reception; ha, ha, ha.
Your Woman, Madam! I thought a Person of your Rank knew how to treat a Gentleman better.
And I thought a Person of your Years might have understood better, than to make Love to one of mine.
My years, Madam! I'm not so old —Can I help my being in Love with you?
No more can Favourite being in Love with you.
You are always witty upon me, Madam — I'd have her to know I love a young Fellow as well as her self.Aside.

'Tis for my extravagant Nephew that I am despisd, that Complicated piece of Vice, whose head-strong Courses, and Luxurious Life, Will ruine both your Peace and Fortune. I saw him a little while ago, enter one of those Schools of Poverty, a Gaming House in St. Martins Lane.
'Tis false.
Nay, Madam, I dare say 'tis true— Yonder goes his Man, I'll call him and convince you.Ex. and re enter with Hector.
He cannot be so ungrateful, after my last Favours. — Hector, where's your Master?
Where e'er his Person is—his Heart is with your Ladyship, Madam; I dare answer for him.
That's Foreign to my Question; Where is he?
Yes, yes, he's a fit person to inquire of truly.
So I am Sir; for no body knows my Master's out∣goings and his in-comings better than my self.
Come, you shall tell me— Dorante says he saw him go into a Gaming House.
Discover'd — Nay, then I must bring him off — Why, that is true▪ Madam.
Perfidious!
But, Madam, it is to take his leave upon my word— he's gone to play, with a design to play no more.
Now, Madam, who was in the right?
Is it possible a Man can be so base!
There are Men, Madam, that ne'er was guilty of such Crimes.

But, Madam, you won't hear me— my Master is making all the speed he can, to put himself in a condition to
keep his word with you, he is shaking his Elbows, ratling the Box, and breaking his Knuckles for haste — he has sent me Post for his last Auxiliary Guinea's, which when he has thrown off, he'll lay himself at your Feet, with full resolution never to touch Box or Dice more.
A likely matter, truly.
So it is, Madam —for he'll put it out of his power to offend again.
'Till he has a new Recruit.
Madam, your Ladyships most Humble Servant, I must fly, for my Master will think every our Seven till he's here.
Now, Madam, are you convinc'd —Will you yet accept a Heart devoted only to your Charms?
No more of your Fustian—'tis unseasonable, don't provoke me to use you worse than good Manners will allow▪ I respect your Age, but hate your —
Well, Scornful Maid, take up with your Gamester, do; you'll be the first that repents it: And so farewell.
Oh! my too constant Heart, Canst thou still hold the Image of this Faithless Man — And yet methinks I'd fain reclaim him—I'll try the last Extremity.

Q.L: For when from Ill a Proselite we gain,
The Goodness of the act rewards the Pain;
But if my honest Arts successless prove,
To make the Vices of his Soul remove,
I'll dye—or rid me from this Tyrant Love.

DIV3.STAGE: The End of the Third Act.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT IV.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Valere with a Box and Dice in his Hand, as from Play, to a Porter—Betty Listning.

SP.P: SO, thus far I have follow'd this Porter; here I'll ob∣serve who he wants—I'm sure 'tis against the Interest of Mr. Lovewell.
From a Lady, say'st thou! and must be deliver'd into my own Hand—
As I imagin'd.

Prithee Fellow, do'st know what 'tis to interrupt a Gamester when his Fortune's at stake — — Seven or Eleven have more Charms now than the brightest Lady in the King∣dom. Opens the Letter Reads—Humph—pursuant to what I told you before, Angelica, That a declaration of Love wou'd not be disagreeable, I confirm my words in a Golden showr—'tis what I believe most acceptable to a Man in your Circumstances (Well guess'd, 'e Faith) a Bill for One Hundred Pounds payable at sight—Monsieur La Porter, your very humble Servant — Tell the Lady I am hers most obediently — it requires no other Answer, till I fly my self to return my Thanks.
Yes, Sir,Exit Porter.

What must I do now, prove a Rogue, and betray my Friend Lovewell—If I accept this present, I must make my returns in Love; for when a Widow parts with Money, 'tis easie to read the valuable Consideration she expects: But then Angelica, the Dear, the Faithful Maid——But then a Han died Guinea's, the dear tempting sight. Ha! Lovewell, thou com'st in good time, for my Virtue's staggering.
I have been seeking you all the Town over.

And what News? thou hast a very lovesick Coun∣tenance,
the Widow has us'd thee scurvily I know.

Beyond all bearing—Valere, thou ever wert my Friend, prithee instruct me —help to find the cursed Rival out—'ts not the Fool Marquiss I'm convinc'd; but some lurking Villain, some Wretch unworthy of her Charms— else her Vaniy wou'd ne'r conceal him.
Hold, hold, Friend, you run on a little too fast — What wou'd your Mightiness do now, supposing you disco∣ver'd this detested Rival?
I'd force him to renounce her; or lose my Life, and leave her free.
Why, then I have such a respect for this Gentleman, that I must preserve him from your Lyon like fury.

Ha! Dost thou know him then —— Oh! I charge thee by our past years of Friendship, and by my pece of Mind, which this Cruel Woman takes eternally away, tell me but who he is, describe him to me; is he a Gentle∣man?
Yes, Faith.
And handsome?
The Ladies think so.

Tell but his Name, that my Revenge may reach him; Hast thou a Friend more dear than I — No, no, thy Companions are no Friends; Gamesters and Profligates— whom in thy reflecting Hours I know thou hates — She is not fit for one of these.
The Spark is a little given to Gaming, I confes — yet holds his Nose as high as your Widow, I can tell you that.
Prithee trifle no longer with me —— nor do not jest with Pains like mine.
Do you know her Hand?
Death, does she Write to him?
These Credentials will confirm she does.

STAGE.HI: Gives him her Letter, with the Bill.

SP.P:
Confusion to thee—and a Bill for Money — away, it cannot be—by Hell, the Company thou keeps has taught
thee to be a Villain; thou hast abus'd her Honour, which I will justify: Draw.

Here's a Rogue now —when I have withstood a Temptation wou'd have shock a Permit— he'd cut my Throat for not taking his Mistress from him—Well, these Romantick Lovers are whimsical things — Hark ye Chales, I believe you know I am no Coward; and if your Fighting fit remains on you till to Morrow Morning — I'll meet you when and where you please, bu I am engag'd now—as you may see, farewell—shewing him Box, &c.Exit.
What Man, but wou'd for ever scorn, despise this false Ingrate—but I'm a slave to Love, and bound with such a Chain, no Injuries can break — Something must be done, but what I know not.Exit.
So, my Lady has brought her self into a fine premu∣nie; Well, I'm glad I heard all this, and hope to make it turn to Mr. Lovewell's Advantage—who is a Generous Man, and deserves a Countess.Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE Changes to Lady Wealthy's Lodging.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Weal.
SP.P: So, thus far I'm successful; the Porter says he was Transported with the Letter, and will instantly be here— Who's there? Enter Footman Bid my Woman come hi∣ther.
She's not within, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Weal.
SP.P: How, not within!
Here she comes.

SP.SPEAKER: L Weal.
SP.P: Hey! where have you been to put your self in this heat?
Speaking to a Relation, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Weal.
SP.P: A Relation; sure 'twas a warm Conference has left such signs on't in your Cheeks—Set my Toylet—I'll throw these mournful Blacks away—adorn'd in chearful White receive and Charm my Heroe.
Mr Lovewell▪ Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Weal.
SP.P: No, Fool; When did you ever see me Dress at an old Lover He's mine, securely mine: But Valere, the Gay, the Rover, the unconquer'd Rambler, he, he alone deserves my Care.
Madam, Might I presume to speak—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Weal.
SP.P: Your Nonsence freely; I am in a good humour, and can bear it all.
Then Valere is the most ungrateful— and Mr Love∣well the most accomplish'd of any Man breathing.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Weal.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, And this is your Speech—Lovewell is beholding o you truly, and Mr. Valere shall know his Friend.
I hate him, Madam: And you have reason.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Weal.
SP.P: Peace. I find I gave you too much Liberty.
Madam, a Letter for your Ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Weal.
SP.P:
Human! from Lovewell, I know the Hand, some Compliment, some dismal Madrigal, or tedious Ditty, in wore Prose! am sure. opens it Ha! my own Bill, what means this ——
Madam
— You have bestowed your Favours unworthily; notwithstanding this proof, I woud have fought, de∣fended you beyond demonstration, but your new Choice declin'd the Swor a — and that Love I so long languish'd for. Your Neglected, njur'd, but still Faithful LOVEWELL.
Base Traytor, is this a Man of Honour? This the return to my Advances — It is impossible — He has way laid the Porter, Bib'd him, and deceiv'd me.
Indeed he has not, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Weal.
SP.P: Why, know you ought of this?
Yes, I can tell you all ——If you will promise to Interpret for the good of him who loves you truly.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Weal.

SP.P: Turn back, bright Fair, and listen to an Action Glorious as Conde, Luxenburg, or Hess, or any He that ever grac'd the Field.
More Plagues!—I begin to grow weary of this Train of Fools—Pray make your Story short, Sir.
I'll be as Concise as the Heroick Deed—Veni, Vidi, Vici, as Caesar said.
Over whom were this Conquest? — Your Footman and your Taylor.
No, Madam, over my Rival Valere.
Ha! Where meet you that Report?
Every where— The World says you are in Love with him—'Tis all the Discourse at the Chocolate House
Confusion! I am become so wretched — I shall be sung in Ballads shortly.

Having a profound Respect for your Ladyship — Away flew I to his Lodgings— where I had no sooner en∣ter'd, but the Memory of your Wrongs— set the stormy Marks of Anger on my Brow—Sir, said I, —Sir, said he, your most humble Servant — Sir, said I, — here is a Rumour spread abroad, prejudicial to the Reputation of a Lady whom I have honour'd with my Esteem.
Honour'd! Oh, audacious!

And Report says you are the Author—who, I said he, in the meakest, humblest Tone, that ever Lover beg'd in— frightned out of his Wits —Her Name, I pray—which when I had told him, and bid him Draw, he poorly dis∣claim'd his Passion, and said, I might take you with all his Heart, for he wou'd not fight—At which I stept up to him, saying, Seavez Vous Monsieur du Lansquenet——that is as much as to say, in English, a Flip of the Nose, Madam—at which the good Gentleman pull'd off his Hat, and made me the lowest Bow; and I, in Triumph, left — Now my Re∣ward—My Reward, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Weal.
SP.P: Your reward, never to see me more, for tho I have Valour I know this story false——and you made up of Cow∣ardice, de'e hear—If ever my doors are open Enter 3 F∣men to this bold Intruder more, I'll have your Liveries pull'd over your Ears.Exit.

Gone, I durst have Sworn she wou'd have Married me for the News—Now here's a good Invention lost—Ah poor Monsieur Markee, thou'lt never thrive with these Women of Quality—I must to sum rich Toothless City Dame—
On them my Courage, and my Shame may pass,
These Court end Wits, discover me an Ass.Exit.

Well I have not patience any longer to see this Ma∣ster of mine Play—I find which way he's going —Od'so here's his Father—how shall I send him away—for if he shou'd see his Son come out of this Gaming-House, we shall be un∣done again — Enter, Sir Tho. Valere Oh Sir, I have been all over the Town to look you—
For what pray? did my last greeting please you so well, that you have a mind to more on't?—Where's the Rake your Master?
Oh Sir, happy, happy beyond Expression — he's with Angelica, who has presented him with her Picture, set round with Gems of Inestimable value.
Ha! say'st thou so Boy? and is he likely to carry Angelica?
Carry her, Sir, why the business is done, and nothing wanting but your presence, with a Lawyer to sit 'em for the Priest —Good, Sir, make haste — —

I'll be there in an instant—And shall I be a Grand-father add — I cou'd find in my heart to give thee six pence for thy News—And I will too —there Hector drink your young Master and Lady's Health, Sirrah — Ah my dear boy Jm, I forgive thee all —I'am so trans∣ported I think an Age till I embrace thee.Exit.

'Fore George if this Old fellow finds me in a Lye, as he most certainly will; for if Angelica hears my Master is at play again, she'll never have him that's sure too—I must let him know what I have done, and get him in the mind to go this hour to Angelica—or Hector's bones will pay for't.

Q.L: To serve my Master, I a Lye may tell
But wou'd not suffer, when I mean it well.Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE Discovers a Gaming Table with Valere, Count Cog∣die, and other Gentlemen at Hazard, with several Rakes and Sharpers, waiting round the Table; a Box-Keeper and At∣tendance.

SP.P: Come—Seven—What do you set Gentlemen? Box-Keep. Seven's the Main.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Gent.
SP.P: That.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Gent.
SP.P: Ten Pieces.
The Devil's in the Dice—There, Sir, a Hundred GuineasAngerlyCogdie ratling the Box, and considering where to throw.
Knock where you are, Sir.
I am at the fairest only throws out the Dice Come and that little Silver, too.
Four to Seven.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Rake.
SP.P: Mr. Cogdie, to three a Crown, shall I?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Rake.
SP.P: To three, and Eleven, Guineas, If you please.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Sharp,
SP.P: Here's three Crowns to Eleven, and if I lose, by all that's good I know not where to eat.
To 1 Rake.You go to three a Crown to second Rake you to three, and Eleven Guineas to Sharper you shall go yours to Eleven Jack.
Pray, Sir, throw away, don't hold the Box all night.
There Shakes the Box and throws three you're in once Gentlemen.
We go again.
With all my heartShakes the Box again, and throws four.
Four, Trae-Ace.
There Gentlemen, I have brought you off again.to the Rakes.
You did not throw our your Dice fair, and I'll not yield it.
Judgment Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Gent.
SP.P: I think 'twas fair enough.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Gent.
SP.P: Ay, ay, a man may throw his Dice how he pleases.
Sir, I say this Hat's white.in a Passion.
I say so too.
'Tis false, 'tis Black.
As you say, I think it is Black.
No, Sir, 'tis neither Black nor White.
Nay, very likely, Sir,—he has lost his Money and now he grows mutinous.
Come, Pray Gentlemen don't quarrel, and i'll ask it Round.
Ask what, you Blockhead? whether his Hat's Black or White.Tosses a pair of Dice in his Face.
No, Master, whether you won the Money or not.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Gent.
SP.P: He won it fairly. Come Valere I'll lend thee ten Pieces, set boldly, I'll warrant the Luck, Boy.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Gent.
SP.P: Ay, ay, come whose is the Box.
'Tis mine —

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Gent.
SP.P: Throw a Main then.
Five.
Five's the Main.
There —take all.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Gent.
SP.P: That—

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Gent.
SP.P: That—
Where I was last. Now little Dice.
Shake your Dice.
There, Sir, Shakes the Dice and throws Duce, A— Oh, Burn 'em.
Duce, Ace.
Out—Give me the Box—Six.
Six is the Main.
There, Sir, if you dare throw at it.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Gent.
SP.P: That—

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Gent.
SP.P: That—
At you all—Shakes the Box, and throws Quater Duce.
Six. Quator Duce, you've won it, Sir.
Um!seems Disorder'd.
Come Seven.Throws.
Seven's the Main.
A hundred Guineas.
Now little Dice —
Not another Nick sureSpeaks as Valere is going to throw the Dice.
Nick by Juno—
Cinque Duce.
Oh! Blood! and Death! and Fire!Rises and walks about in a Passion.
NineThrows.
Nine's the Main.
There, Sir, I'll set you two Hundred Guineas upon that Note.
Note, Sir! whose Note is it Pray?
Why 'tis very good, Sir, 'tis upon Sir F—s Ch—d
At it, Egad.Throws.
Nine. Cinque and Quator, the Box is Due.

SP.L: Um!Throws away the Dice, breaks the Box.

SP.P: Sir, I did not see you,—and I won it fairly.
The Devil, I that understand Play so well, to be bubled of my Money—Sir, I say this Hat's White—who dares say the Contrary?
Not I indeed Sir.
I say 'tis Black.
Why, as you say, I think 'tis Black.
I say, Sir, 'tis neither Black nor White.
Then it shall be Green, Blew, Red or Yellow, or what you Please, Sir. I have more Manners than to quarrel now I'm on the winning side, ha, ha, ha,

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Gent.
SP.P: Prethee don't quarrel with him, you'll get nothing by it. Valere will fight you know.
And so will I, Sir You're all a parcell of —If ever I play upon the Square again—I'll give 'em leave to make Dice of my Bones.
Ha, ha, ha, hold, let me pay my Debts. There, Sir—to 2 Gent.
You owe a Box, Sir. an Please you,
There—Gives a Shilling.
You owe me a Teaster for a back-hand-tip, a little while a go Master.
There you Doggives him Six Pence.
Thank you Master—I'll thank any Gentleman that will put that Shilling in the Box.
Ay, here he is.
Come Seven.
Seven's the Main.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Gent.
SP.P: That —

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Gent.
SP.P: That—
'Tis mine.
Eleven —

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Gent.
SP.P: I never saw such Fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Gent.
SP.P: Here's the last of a Hundred, if Luck turn not I'm Broke.
Save you Gentlemen — may one fling off a Guinea or two with you ——This while Cogdie sits disordered and plays by himself at another Table.
Ay, a hundred if you please, a pert young Buble this, stung Six —
Six is the Main.
Fifty Pieces, Sir.
Well said Stripling —— Down with 'em —— Six or a Dozen Dice—Duce Ace— Ah split it —
Duce Ace.
Out, Sir, give me Fifty Guineas, Sir.
There 'tis, Sir.—Cogdie rises and comes to Angelica.
To AngelicaSir, will you do me the Favour to let me go two Pieces with you, I am just Stript.
Withall my heart, Sir. Come Gentlemen Throws set Boldly—
Five's the Main.
A Hundred Guineas.
Along throws 'tis mine.Sweeps the Money.
Five, Tray, Duce.
To Cogd.There's your two Pieces, Sir.
I go the four, Sir. If you Please?
By and by, Sir. You shall.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Gent.
SP.P: I'm broke. But, I'll be here again Instantly.Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Gent.
SP.P: I'll throw of this Stake—If Luck turn not I must home for Recruits too.
Come on then, Sir, Six.Throws.
Six is the Main.
In my Conscience, I believe this young Dog will Strip us all. There, Sir.
And there, Sir.Sweeps the Money.
A Dozen.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Gent.
SP.P: I hope you'll stay till my return?
If these Gentlemen can hold me play.
I hope Gentlemen, you won't stay late for fear of the Press-masters, here was two Gangs last night before twelve a Clock.All the Sharpers sneek off, and leave Angel. and Val. together.
Pshaw, hang the Press-masters, come, Sir, Five—
Five's the Main.
That upon Five.
Nick.—
Five, Quator Ace, you owe a Box, Sir.
Confusion! did ever Man see the like? That Watch at 20 GuineasSets a Gold Watch.
Dun, Sir, NineThrows.
Nine's the Main.
'Tis mine.Throws.
Nine Six and Three, a main above a Box.
Furies and Hell—That Ring at ten Guineas.
Ha, ha, ha, withall my heart, Sir, Six again,Throws.
Six is the Main.
Nick again, ha, ha, ha.
Six, Cinque Ace, two Mains above a Box.
The Devil—i'll set you a hundred Guineas upon Ho∣nour, Sir.
I beg your Pardon, Sir, I never play upon Honour with Strangers—If you have nothing else to set your hum∣ble Servant.
Death shall he carry off my Money thus—hold, Sir, Friends will be here presently, I'll borrow some of them.
That's baulking my hand —I can't stay, Sir, have you nothing else?
Yes, one thing, but that is dearer to me than my Life
What can that be pray?
'Tis a Picture, the Original of which is nearest to my Soul—Kisses it.
I'ish —a trisse —Oh my heart—yet you shan't say I'm ungenerous—what ere you value it at, I'll answer it.
Value it at—It is not to be valued.
Then you'll not set it, Sir, your Servant.
Stay, Sir, — Luck may turn—I'll set the Diamonds at 200 Guineas.
Oh Villain—Well, Sir, Seven—.
Seven's the Main.
Four or Seven.
I bar the first throw.
Bar.

DIV3.STAGE: Angelica throws two or three times and then wins it.

SP.P: 'Tis mine, Sir.
Four Tray Ace, you owe me three Boxes, Sir.
Eternal Furies—lost—He shall restore it, or I'll Cut his Throat —Well, Sir, take the Diamonds, but I must have the Picture—
The Picture, Sir?
Ay, the Picture, Sir.
I won it, Sir, and I shan't restore it, I assure you.
But you shall restore it, Sir, er'e you and I part.
If I shou'd draw a Duel upon my hands here—I'm in a fine condition—Aside. Nay, Sir, if you are angry good by—
Nay, nay, nay, runs between him and the Door you shan't carry off the Picture by Hercules—Looke'e, Sir, either take my Bond, or fight me for't—Draws.
Sir—trembling what shall I do, I must be oblig'd to discover my self—AsideEnter 1 and 2 Gentlemen

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Gent.
SP.P: Hold Valere.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Gent.
SP.P: What's the meaning of this?La hold of Valere.
Ha! a lucky escape.—Runs off.
Away, stand off, or I shall y passage through you Traytor, Dog—Oh I cou'd tear —Cut off these hands that laid the Jewel down — and my heart, for having once consented —Walks about ng.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Gent.
SP.P: What can be the cause of this Passion?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Gent.
SP.P: Ho, he has lost his Money—prithee don't let that trouble thee—I'll lend thee more—Come lets throw for the Box.
Throw for the Devil— No, henceforth a Gamster is my Foe—Nor shou'd the Indies bribe me even to touch a Die, nor after this moment, will Ie're set foot in such a House again—

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Gent.
SP.P: The Man is Mad.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Gent.
SP.P: Prithee lets go seek out better Company.Exit.
Now I behold what a Monster this darling Sin has made me, and loath my self for my long race of Folly —

Q.L: Now I repent, but oh it comes to late,
And 'tis but Justice now that she shou'd hate;
He that flys Vertue still to follow Vice,
'Tis fit, like me, he loose his Paradice.
