SP.P: WHat shall I do? there's no going near Angelica, the action I have done carries such a Face, that she can ne'r forgive me.Enter Hector.

Another 'scape, Sir, another 'scape, your Father was just at the Gaming-House Door upon the hunt for you, — but thanks to my Wit, I found away to send him pack∣ing, he's gone to Angelica's with a Lawyer, follow him, fol∣low him, Sir,—if he gets there before you, the Old Gentle∣man will believe me no more—for I told him you staid for him there— ha; he minds me not, Sir, Sir, don't you hear me?— —
No, I'll neither hear, nor see, nor eat, nor drink, nor ever rest again.

Ah▪ the Devil, I shall be as slender as a Hasel-Switch in a little time then, for I suppose I must keep you Compa∣ny in that thn Die —— Ah! what I dded is come to pass— What then is all the Money lost?
Money, my Life, my Soul is lost.
Hey day, what's the matter now
The Picture.
The Picture, Sir,— with a Mercy on us, shake your Pockets, shake you Pocke, Sir.runs to Valere, and shaes his Coat Pocket.
Hold off, I tell thee I've lost it at I lay.
Why then you have plaid fair—why what will you do now, Sir?
Cut your Throat, Sirrah, and then my own.claping hold of Hector.
'Twas none of my fault, Sir.half weeping.
Oh! no, it was my own, for had I ta'en thy Council this Curse had been prevented.
Ay Sir, but a Gamester's Life was the most Genteel of any—their Fob was a Fund, and their Hands Philoso∣phers Stones. Ay, Sir.
No more—go fetch me a Book—sits down.
What Book, Sir?
The first that comes to your hand, no matter which.
Here's Seneca, Sir.
Well read —Was ever Man so unfortunate.walk∣ing about in a thinking posture.
Who, I read Seneca, Sir?
Why not?
I seldom read any thing, Sir, but Almanacks.
Oh read, read at a venture. To lose upon seven when the Chance was four! Confusion!stamps.

reads—Be not taken with the glittering Dreams of Riches, their possession brings Trouble, Tranquility is a cer∣tain equality of Mind, which no condition of Fortune can either exalt or depress. If his Fortune be good, he tempers it, if bad, he masters it.
The Devil was in me, that I cou'd not leave off when I was a winner.

What is the end of Ambition and Avarice, we are but Stewards of what we falsely call our own. All those things which we pursue with so much hazzard, for which we break Faith and Friendship, what are they but the meer depositor of Fortune, and not ours, but already inclining to∣wards a new Master. — Now will I be hang'd, if Seneca himself was not given to aming.—Sir, don't you think this looks like a Moral Reflection after a Loss.— —In
my Conscience, I'm half in the Mind that he play'd away a Mistresses Picture too——
Ha! name it not, for if thou dost, I'll shake thee in∣to Atoms.—shaking him.
Ah Sir, I've done, I've done, —But, Sir, this Seneca was a wondrous Man—was he ever in London, Sir?
No, he lived at Rome.—Not one in ten, Oh wretch∣ed Luck.
That's a long way off—I thought indeed 'twas some∣thing made his Morals so little minded.—Come, Sir, Courage.
Yes, I'll to the Camp, there in the service of my Country, expiate my Follies.

To the Camp, Sir, what do you mean? Odsbud, Sir, go to Angelica this Minute, and Marry her out of hand, she does not know you have lost the Picture, and when once she's secure, if she asks for it, stop her Mouth with Kisses, Sir.

Well, I will go, if but to take my leave of her— For I much fear she'll read guilt in my Face———
This I resolve whatever Fates, in store,
To touch the Curst Infectious Dice no more.
Ay, stick you but there, and I warrant we prosper.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE the Lady Wealthy's House.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lady Wealthy, Mrs. Betty to her.

SP.P: Madam, Mr. Lovewell to wait on your Ladiship.

How shall I see him! Shame and Confusion rises in my Face, yet it is not in my temper to own my self in the wrong, if he upbraids me, this is his last visit, bring him up— Enter Mr. Lovewell. I suppose you come triumphant, but know, I give account of my actions to no Man. Am free, and will so remain.

'Tis my hard Fortune still to be mistaken, my Love's too blind to think you do amiss.—I have since been with Va∣lere, sworn to him the Letter was a plot of mine, the Hand
and Bill all counterfeit, to satisfie my jealous scruple if there were Affairs between ye, he believed it, and your Honour's free from all ill Tongues—And the Wretch doom'd to be hated still,—am come to take my everlasting leave.

This generosity shocks me— aside. Farewell, you have clear'd me to your Rival, but to your self can say she was ungrateful and despised me, Love without esteem is a forc'd Plant and wants its Root, therefore my ill conduct parts us, and thank your generous carriage for this confessi∣on,—Great Spirits hardly yield themselves to blame.

Nor are you, I have not watch'd so many Years your Temper, each turn and sally of your Mind, but I can judge it right, Honour is centur'd in your Soul, nor wou'd you wrong it in an essential part. All your little Affecta∣tions are but the effects your Glass produces, which tells ye, Beauty like yours, may take ten thousand Liberties.
You have chose a cunning way to move my Heart, when I was arm'd for Accusations to extenuate my faults. And if I cou'd persuade my self to trust a Man, I think it wou'd be you.
Oh cherish that kind Opinion, and if ever you do repent it, proclaim me to the World, A Villain.
This I resolve in favour of your noble Usage, to banish from my House, that senceless Train of Fop Admi∣rers, which I always laught at, and only kept to feed my Vanity.

On my Knees I thank you, but do not, do not, dash my transports by delay.—Your Year of Widowhood is just expir'd,——reward my constant Love and make me happy, a Husband will fright the Fool pretenders from approaching, and these fond Arms secure you ever mine.
Bless me, is the Man mad? here wou'd be a strange leap indeed, from Mortal Odds into Matrimony. No, no, a, little longer time must try you first.

If time be now required, you may defer my Joys till Age has strew'd my Head with hoary Hairs, for from
my very Infancy I have ador'd you—'tis but a Mont ago when my auspicious Stars inclined you to a sit of Mercy. —I flew, got a Licence, came with eager hopes, and you denied to see me, the same Authority will do now.—Nor will I leave you, till your Hand is mine.
Betty, come to my aid, here's an audacious Man will Marry me, in spight of my Teeth, this very instant.
Oh Madam, the luckiest Moment in the World, I have been just looking in Erra Pater, and there's the happiest Conjunction—And the Chaplain sauntring about the Gar∣den's ready for Imployment.
Nay, look not back, your Eyes consent, and I'll have no denial.
Well, this is the maddest thing.

SP.L: The wandring Fair, are by long Courtships kind,
And constant Love does luckiest Minutes find.

SP.P: Lovewell and my Sister happy pair,—I am only curst in a loose Reprobate, whom no Chance, no Obligations can fix, I must resolve to blot him from my Soul — but how hard 'tis to efface the first Impression—Valere, if I can part with thee, Mankind will be upon the square, thy Uncle may succeed, Old or Young, for I shall never look with liv∣ing Eyes again. — Let me think,—to lose my Picture — Oh unpardonable fault.—

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Dorante and Mrs. Fav. at a distance.

SP.P: Now, Sir, is your time, she is horridly out of humour, I know 'tis with Valere, for nothing else makes her so.

Madam, I hope you will pardon my intrusion, when 'tis to warn you of approaching Danger, I can prove to you my Nephew has broke all his Oaths, and played with the veryest Rakes the Town affords in a publick Gaming-House.
Malice, malice, all.
As this is true or false, may I your Love enjoy.
Suppose it true, am I confin'd to make my choice in your Family—or indeed to choose at all,—perhaps I'll never Marry.—
Oh say not so, let not so much Beauty lose the end of its Creation—You should bless the World with your Increase.

Methinks you are too much in the Wain to think of Increase,—however I am yet resolved on nothing— and desire to be freed from importunity—'Tis well you Enter Valere and Hector. Are come, your Uncle has been using all his Rhetorick to supplant you.
The Day's our own, she's in a pure Humour.aside.
No Clandestine Dealings, Uncle, I beseech you, give me fair Play, and let the Lady choose—
With what assurance he approaches.aside.
However, her Choice may go, I know rves her most—I'm no Gamester, Sir,—her of rest shall ne'r be broke by me.
That I dare swear.

No reflections, Sir, on so Follies, you in your Youth doubtless had your sha, — tho' now you are past 'em, and only rail at what you can't enjoy—but I in my full strength and vigour give 'em over, resolving never to in∣dulge the tempting Vice agen.
This you have often sworn, and as often broke your Vows.
I have, but 'tis in the power of Fate to make me do't again, and what's past this Lady has forgiven.
To end your disputes, Mr. Dorante, I'll now own to you, that my Heart has been long since given to Valere—and this Morning I renewed my Vows.
Oh transport, now Uncle I hope you are satisfied.
No, Sir, I am not satisfied—nor can I believe what she says real, without condemning her Judgment.
A strange positive Old Man this —Valere pray clear his Understanding,— shew him the Present I made you to day, then let him judge who I design my Heart for.
Ha! what shall I say.aside.
Oh! I'm thunderstruck.aside.
Oh spare his Age, Madam, I forgive him, he is my Uncle, and I wou'd not triumph,—'twould make him mad should I produce the Picture.
No, no, fear not, 'tis rather Charity, for since he re∣fuses to believe my Words, 'tis but reason he should have O∣cular Demonstration.
He that doubts what's uttered by that Tongue, is un∣worthy of your farther care—therefore pardon me, Madam, a thing so sacred as your Image, never shall convince him.
Well hinted, I faith.aside.
But when I desire it, methinks you shou'd not refuse; Obedience becomes a Lover.
Lost agen.aside.

SP.L: You ever shall command me.—feeling first in one Pocket then in t'other.
Ha! where did I put it?

SP.P: Humph.lifting up his Eyes.
I am amaz'd at his Impudence,aside.
Bless me, sure I did not leave it in the Bed—which way shall I come off.—aside—Hector—
Sir—looking very simply.
Did you not see a Picture no where to Day?
A Picture, Sir!—in a kind of a fright.
Ay, a Picture, what makes you look so, Sirrah, ha! I suspect your Rogueship has done something with it.
Oh dear Sir, —trembling.
Where is it, speak Rascal, or I'll cut your Ears off.draws.
Oh Sir, forgive me, and I'll tell you the whole truth
What means the Fellow?aside.
What will you tell me, Sirrah?

Why Sir, fearing that your Pocket might be pickt, or your Lodgings rob'd, and you might lose the Picture, and that I thought wou'd break your Heart, knowing how much you did esteem the piece, I took it, Sir, to a famous Painter of my Acquaintance to have it copied,—Sir, that's all.
A well invented Tale.aside.
Fly Sirrah, and fetch it.Slaps him on the Back.
Yes Sir.going.
Oh you may spare your pains, Sir, — the Picture is already here — pulls it out now Sir, do you blush.
I am amaz'd to think how she came by it.aside.
Ruin'd past redemption—Oh, oh, oh,— that such a compleat Lie should turn to no account.aside.
Ungrateful Man.
How, how's this?

Is this the price you set upon my Favours—the sight of this should mind you of your Duty—if I remember those were your Words——but I presume you meant it should remind you of a last Stake—how have I been de∣ceived. —Is it possible thou couldst be so base to expose my Picture at a common Board, amongst a Crew of Re∣vellers.
Madam.
Be dumb, and make no Impudent Excuses.
Dol, dol, dery, dol, dery, dol.Sings.

No, Madam, I shall not study to excuse my self, on∣ly this I am not guilty of all your charge, for there was none in presence when I lost it, but the Youth that won it. Who had not lived to have brought it you, had not an unlucky chance prevented me.

Then to conceal your treachery, you wou'd have com∣mitted Murder— excellent Moralist.——But, Sir, the pri∣vacy of the Act you boast of—does not in the least exte∣nuate your Crime; I told you whilst you kept that Picture, my Heart was yours, but you grew weary of the Trifle, and restored it back, and now I have liberty to give to whom I please.
I hope you are satisfied now Nephew, ha, ha, ha.
I am with every thing this Lady is pleased to inflict, I know she can use me worse than I deserve—I own the foulness of my guilt, and will not hope for pardon.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir Tho. Valere with a Lawyer.

SP.P: Nay then, we are Friendless indeed,— Sir, Sir, shall I see what Seneca says upon this Head?Aside to Valere.
Away, and Plague me not.— — Ha, my Father.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: I'm Blest beyond Expression, Blest.—Madam, I wish you Joy: My Son, I have brought Mr. Demur the Lawyer, — I'll reserve but Five Hundred a Year for my self, — the rest is thine, Boy,— full Two Thou∣sand Pound per Annum.—.
Sir Thomas, Your Words carry a Meaning in 'em — which I'm a Stranger to.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: Meaning, Madam,— I hope my Son and you understand one another's Meaning, — and I understand it toe, Madam. — Come, Mr. Demur, where are the Wri∣tings of my Estate? — He shall make thee a swinging Jointure, my Girl—
You must Pardon me, Sir Thomas,— my Mind's alter'd.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: How! Did you not Promise?
Suppose I did. When a Man breaks all his Oaths to me, I know no reason I shou'd keep my Word with him, —
Ah Hector, Hector, what will become of thee?Aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: Why, I understood these Quarrels were made up— and as a Token of your being reconcil'd, you made him a Present of your Picture. —
True, — and that's the thing that parts us.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: What do you mean?
He Gam'd it away, Brother; now do you under∣stand her?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: Malice and Marriage, Brother, ill becomes your Years. — She does not mean it so.
Indeed but I o.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sr Tho.
SP.P: Say you so, Madam, — then I'll do you Justice immediately Draws. Sirrah, I'll save the Hangman a Labour,— I will, you Bastard.
Do, Kill me Sir; you shall find I will not vent one Groan,— for my Soul has ta'en its Flight already, — My base Ingratitude has deeper stab'd my Heart, than now your Sword can do.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: Say you so, Sirrah,— then I hope you'll live to want nothing, for I'll take care you shall have nothing to support your Extravagance.— Mr. Demur, I desire you to make my Will this Minute,— and put the ungraci∣ous Rogue down a Shilling.—Sirrah, I charge you never to come in Sight of me, or my Habitation more;— nor, do you hear, dare to own me for your Father. — Go, Troop Sirrah, I shall hear of your going up Holbourn-Hill in a little time. —
So, there's all my Wages lost. —Aside.
Ha! this Usage shocks me.Aside.

Sir, I promise you to obey you to a Tittle, — and this Undutiful Child shall ne'er offend you with his Presence more. — You but Enjoin, but I before had Chose, for England now would be the worst of Fates.
My Heart beats as if the Strings were breaking.—

Madam, there is but one Request that I will make — then take my Leave for ever, and if you grant it not, I shall be so much more Unhappy. — My being Disinhe∣rited weighs not a Hair, compar'd with what I've lost in losing you, whom my Soul prefers before all Wealth, Friends or Family.— Then, where shou'd I ask Pardon but where I most have Injur'd? — Thus, on my Knees, I beg you not to hate my Memory, nor sffer the Follies which I have now Cashier'd for ever from my Breast; — (but Oh too late) to drive my Name as distant as my Body from you, — sometimes vouchsafe to think on lost Valere.
There is nothing so indifferent but we think of it sometimes.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: Sirrah— begone I say.Pushes him.
I have done.— Now Madam, Eternally adieu.

Shall I see him ruin'd — no — that wou'd be barbarous beyond Example — Valere come back, shou'd I forgive you all — Wou'd my Generosity oblige you to a sober Life.— Can you upon Honour (for you shall swear no more) forsake that Vice that brought you to this low Ebb of Fortune.—

Ha! Oh let me sold thee in my Repenting Arms— and whisper to thy Soul, that I am intirely Chang'd— Em∣braces her Yes my Love, I swear the Course of Life that I've run hitherto — is grown more hateful to me than Toads or Adders; and I wou'd as soon keep those Animals in my Bosom, whose Sting I know, would Kill me,—as once indulge my former Follies.
Then I am happy. — Know I was the Youth that Won the Picture, and you parted with it to my self.
I shall Die with Joy, that's certain.—Aside.
Then I did not break my Oath entirely, you were excepted, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: How Lucky a Turn is this! Madam your Ex∣ample is too good not to be follovv'd.— Valere, I forgive thee, and Confirm my first Design: — Bless you both.—Now Brother, I hope you'll believe you can't get my Boy's Mistress from him. Ha, ha, ha.
Nor he shall never get a Penny of my Estate Bro∣ther, remember that.—Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: He wants it not.— Ha! Who have we here— my Lady Wealthy, and her Old Lover.
Wish me Joy, Friends, wish me Joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: With all my Heart, for in my Conscience thou de∣serv'st her.—
I wish you Joy, Sister; here let all Quarrels cease.
I over heard your Reconciliation,—and I wish you the same
Oh my Friend! Sure never Man was Blest like me.
Yes, I can boast a Happiness beyond thee, — I that merited her endless Scorn, am by her sweet Forgiving Temper rais'd to lasting Joy.—
I understand you are Married, Madam; and come to wish you Joy. — I do it with a bon cour la Dioble in en Port.—
Oh Monsieur Marke, I'm Infinitely oblig'd to you e'er since your Knight-Errantry with Valere in Defence of my Honour.
A duce of that unlucky Story.—No Words on't now, Madam, I beseech you.
How's that?
By the Honour of France I shall be Discover'd.
Madam, Mrs. Security has brought a Pair of very fine Diamond Earrings to show you, they was lost in Pawn, she says,— and therefore she can afford them an ex∣traordinary Pennyworth.
Bring her in. —
Well, Mrs. Security, are they very fine ones.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Sec.
SP.P:
As fine a Pair as ever Your Ladyship saw in all your Life, Madam▪— Gives her the Earrings Bless
me,— What do I see, my Cousin Robin Skipp; I'm glad to see thee with all my Heart. —To the Marquess.
Do you know what you say, Mrs. Security? — That is a French Nobleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Sec.
SP.P: A Nobleman, — What do you think I don't know my Brother's Son?—
A Pox of such Kindred, — Now all will out.—
Why, how long hast thou been in England, Robert? — I hear thou wert a Footman to the Prince of Conti. — Thy old Master, Sir William asks mightily how thou do'st.
Ha, ha, ha, ha.
How's this, the Marquess of Hazzard a Footman? Ha, ha, ha.
Brother, give me thy Hand. — Hold, now I think on't, keep your distance Friend, — for Valet de Chambre is above a Footman —Struts.
My Footmen, Sir, will show you into the But∣tery; a Horn of Small-Beer may quench your Thirst of Honour. Ha, ha.
This Morning he boasted of his Royal Blood at my Lodgings, — but his Cowardise confirm'd him what he is.—
He told me he was at your Lodgings, and presented you with a Tweague by the Nose. —
How! Scoundrel, beneath my Sword, and there∣fore take this.—Kicks him.
Very fine, very fine Breeding, Gentlemen, truly. — Well this is my Maxim still.—

Q.L: Who once by Policy a Title gains,
Merits above the Fool that's Born to Means.Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Sec.
SP.P:
'Tis dirtily done of you, Mr. Valere, so it is, to Kick a Man for nothing; — His Father, tho' I say it,
was as honest a Man as ever broke Bread, and I could fin in my Heart to, to. —
No more of your Noise,—Wait without there. —

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Tho.
SP.P: Come, come, a Pies of this Nonsence, — Let's have a Dance.

SP.L: Now Vertue's Pleasing Prospect's in my View,
With double Care I'll all her Paths pursue;
And proud to think I owe this Change to you.To Angelica.
Virtue that gives more solid Peace of Mind
Than Men in all their Vicious Pleasures find;
Then each with me the Libertine reclaim,
And shun what sinks his Fortune, and his Fame.

DIV1.HEAD: THE EPILOGUE, Spoke by Mr. VERBRƲGGEN.

LG.L: AS one Condemn'd, and ready to become
For his Offences past, a Pendulum;
Does, e'er he Dies, bespeak the Learned Throng,
Then, like the Swan, Expires in a Song.
So, I (tho' doubtful long which Knot to choose.
Whether the Hangman's, or the Marriage Noose)
Condemn'd Good People, as you see, for Life
To Play that tedious, jangling Game a Wife,
Have but one Word of good Advice to say,
Before the doleful Cart draws quite away.
You Roaring Boys, who know the Midnight Cares
Of Rattling Tatts, ye Sons of Hopes and Fears;
Who Labour hard to bring your Ruin on,
And diligently toil to be undone;
You're Fortune's sporting Footballs at the best,
Few are his Joys, and small the Gamester's Rest:
Suppose then Fortune only rules the Dice,
And on the Square you Play; yet, who that's Wise
Wou'd to the Credit of a Faithless Main
Trust his good Dad's hard-gotten hoarded Gain?
But then such Vultures round a Table wait,
And hovouring watch the Bubble's sickly State;
The young fond Gambler covetous of more,
Like Esop's Dog, loses his certain Store.
Then the Spunge squeez'd by all, grows dry,— And now
Compleatly Wretched, turns a Sharper too;
These Fools for want of Bubbles too, play Fair,
And Lose to one another on the Square;
So Whores the Wealth from numerous Culls they Glean,
Still Spend on Ballies, and grow poor again.
This Itch for day has likewise fatal been,
And more than Cupid, drawn the Ladies in,
A Thousand Guineas for Basset prevails,
A Bait when Cash runs low, that seldom fails;
And when the Fair One can't the Debt defray,
In Sterling Coin, does Sterling Beauty pay.
In vain we Labour to divert your Care,
Nor Song, nor Dance can Bribe your Presence here,
You fly this Place like an Infectious Air.
To yonder happy Quarter of the Town,
You Croud; and your own Fav'rite Stage disown;
We're like old Mistresses, you love the Vice,
And hate us only 'cause we once did Please,
Nor can we find how else 'tis we Deserve,
Like Tantalus 'midst Plenty, thus to Starve.
